Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: The launch date was moved up and architects from multiple teams are blocked until they provide decisions
Story: I stare at the Slack notification blinking on my laptop, the architects from three different teams waiting for my input on the new feature specs. The launch date just got moved up, and everyone’s looking at me to unblock them. My phone buzzes—my partner’s child, Jamie, texting me a picture of the Nintendo Switch he’s been dreaming about. I promised him I’d get it this month, and he’s been counting down the days. I know how much it means to him, especially after everything he’s been through. But the price tag stings, and with the project’s demands, I haven’t had time to check our finances. My mind races: if I don’t buy it, I’ll break my promise and let Jamie down. If I do, I risk our budget, and I’m already stretched thin with work stress. Meanwhile, the team’s waiting, the pressure mounting. I feel torn in two—between being the reliable step-parent Jamie needs and the dependable developer my team expects. My heart pounds as I hover over the “reply” button, caught between two worlds, unsure which one I’ll disappoint.
